shortdesc.p: This section describes the configuration tools available for configuring database access generally, and for managing and tuning the Activity Journal—the database where the Report Server maintains an archive of the data it collects.

shortdesc.p: The configuration.xml file also contains settings for connecting to the four data stores required by Control Center.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The configuration.xml file also contains settings for connecting to the four data stores required by Control Center.

shortdesc.p: The four repository sections contain just a few settings—basically just the <name>, and a pointer to a connection pool section, where the actual connection information for that repository is stored.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The four repository sections contain just a few settings—basically just the <name>, and a pointer to a connection pool section, where the actual connection information for that repository is stored.

shortdesc.p: The last element, <MaxPoolSize>, specifies the maximum number of simultaneous data connections available for each of the four databases.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The last element, <MaxPoolSize>, specifies the maximum number of simultaneous data connections available for each of the four databases.

shortdesc.p: There is a minimum as well as a maximum for each connection pool, but it is not configurable.

topicmeta.shortdesc: There is a minimum as well as a maximum for each connection pool, but it is not configurable.

shortdesc.p: Whenever the operational requirements for one of the repositories begins to exceed the number of connections allocated, you need to reallocate connections to prevent database timeouts.

shortdesc.p: Maximum connection values apply per each server instance, rather than to the Control Center as a whole.

shortdesc.p: As the Report Server gathers data on user activity and policy enforcement, it temporarily stores it in OLTP tables before writing it to the Activity Journal database, where it is available for generating reports.

topicmeta.shortdesc: As the Report Server gathers data on user activity and policy enforcement, it temporarily stores it in OLTP tables before writing it to the Activity Journal database, where it is available for generating reports.

shortdesc.p: By default, the table sync operation is set to occur every 15 minutes, counting from the completion of the previous sync operation.

topicmeta.shortdesc: By default, the table sync operation is set to occur every 15 minutes, counting from the completion of the previous sync operation.

shortdesc.p: Reindexing behavior is configured by four elements in the <DAC> <ActivityJournalSettingConfiguration> <IndexesRebuildOperation> section of the configuration.xml file.

topicmeta.shortdesc: Reindexing behavior is configured by four elements in the <DAC> <ActivityJournalSettingConfiguration> <IndexesRebuildOperation> section of the configuration.xml file.

shortdesc.p: By default, the Report Server automatically runs a data archive operation once a day at 1:30 AM, and moves all data older than 90 days from the Activity Journal tables to the Archive.

topicmeta.shortdesc: By default, the Report Server automatically runs a data archive operation once a day at 1:30 AM, and moves all data older than 90 days from the Activity Journal tables to the Archive.

shortdesc.p: When data is moved from the Activity Journal to the Archive, it is no longer available for generating reports using the Reporter queries—these reflect only whatever data is in the Activity Journal tables.

topicmeta.shortdesc: When data is moved from the Activity Journal to the Archive, it is no longer available for generating reports using the Reporter queries—these reflect only whatever data is in the Activity Journal tables.

shortdesc.p: The fourth database management function involves truncating the archive tables, to prevent them from growing too large.

topicmeta.shortdesc: The fourth database management function involves truncating the archive tables, to prevent them from growing too large.

shortdesc.p: Although none of the operations require that you specify individual table names, it may be useful for administrators to know that the schemas for the three sets of tables.

shortdesc.p: The backup step of the process described above generally involves making copies of the archive tables, so they are available in case you ever need to restore them to another database so you can run reports on them.
